facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1844 of 1967 filed by the State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1844 of 1967. Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated 10th August 1965 of Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 435 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 10th August 1965 of the Allahabad High Court at Allahabad in First Appeal No. 435 of 1954.

facts.text: Pandit Suraj Prasad Dubey donated Rs. 30,000 in 1945 to Collector Shri Govind Narain for construction of a women's hospital in memory of Gomti Devi.

anchor.surface_text: An old, affluent man called Dubey, in a munificent mood, responded to the request of Shri Govind Narain, then Collector of Farrukhabad District, way back in 1945. A promise to donate Rs. 30,000/- was made, on the basis of a matching contribution by Government, for the good cause of a womens hospital in sacred memory of the donors deceased wife, Gomti Devi.

facts.text: Donation conditional on matching contribution by Government and construction by Dubey himself.

anchor.surface_text: Apprehending the tardy ways of government, this anxious soul insisted on his being put in charge of the construction so that the hospital may come into existence, through his diligent hands and in his lifetime, aided of course by government grant and auxiliary voluntary contributions.

facts.text: Foundation stone laid ceremonially by British Indian Governor Sir Maurice Hallet in 1945.

anchor.surface_text: The activist Collector accepted these conditions, received the philanthropic cheques, moved swiftly to get the foundation-stone laid ceremonially by the British Indian Governor of the Province, all in 1945.

facts.text: Shri Govind Narain left the district charge after 1945.

anchor.surface_text: But Shri Govind Narain in the usual course left, the District charge and once his back was turned on the District, things got stuck.

facts.text: Next Collector Shri Bhagwan Sahai wrote to Civil Surgeon in March 1946 about delay.

anchor.surface_text: For the next Collector, Shri Bhagwan Sahai, noticing official stagnation in this matter wrote to the Civil Surgeon in March 1946-four months after Sir Maurice Hallet had planted with, pomp the first stone at the hospital site-

facts.text: District Supply Officer proposed to freeze and divert bricks collected by Dubey for school construction.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing happened however, and to add insult to injury the District Supply Officer sent a chill into the chest of the expectant donor by proposing to freeze the bricks collected by him for the hospital. building and to divert them for the construction of a school,

facts.text: Pandit Suraj Prasad Dubey died in July 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The old man, Dubey, continued to correspond with the District authorities on the hospital project till he was spirited away by death in July 1947

facts.text: Government changed plans, did not grant matching sum, removed foundation stone, and built a 22-bed hospital later after suit.

anchor.surface_text: for instead of constructing the proposed six-bed hospital expeditiously with the additional sum to be brought into the hotchpotch by Government, what transpired was that the plans were changed, the agency visualised in the original understanding given up, governments matching sum never granted and even the foundation stone laid by the Governor of the Province removed.

facts.text: Sons of donor filed suit for return of Rs. 30,000 due to failure of conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The sons of the donor brought the present suit on the ground that the conditions subject to which the sum-of Rs. 30,000/- had been given had been violated that the charity as contemplated had never materialised and a totally different scheme had been belatedly executed.

facts.text: Trial Judge found facts in favor of plaintiffs, including specific terms of donation.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Judge held There is overwhelming and unrebutted oral and documentary evidence which leaves me clear that Pandit Suraj Prasad Dubey, the deceased father of the plaintiffs gave Rs. 30,000/- as his subscription on the terms and conditions challeged in the plaint.

facts.text: Hospital to be constructed on Kannauj Makrand Nagar Road near Phoolmati Temple.

anchor.surface_text: That the hospital would be constructed on Kannauj Makrand Nagar Road near Phoolmati Temple.

facts.text: Hospital named Gomti Devi as suggested by Dubey on 30th October 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Dubeyji suggested the name of the hospital as Gomti Devi by his letter dated 30th October, 1945 which name was accepted by D.M.

facts.text: Dubey to construct hospital according to approved plan with Rs. 30,000 from him and matching from government.

anchor.surface_text: That the hospital would be constructed by Dubeyji according to the plan approved by Government with nice arrangement for maternity and child welfare. That a sum of Rs. 30,000 would be paid by Dubeyji for that purpose.

facts.text: District Government Counsel admitted most terms except completion in near future.

anchor.surface_text: District Government Counsel was examined under 0. 10 rule r C.P.C. he admitted that plaintiffs settled term with defendant Government through Sri Govind Narain the then District Magistrate.

facts.text: High Court accepted all findings of fact by trial judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held, The learned counsel for the appellant has rightly conceded that for the Purpose of this appeal all the findings of fact arrived at by the learned Civil Judge, might be accepted as correct.

facts.text: Supreme Court affirmed facts as found by lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: These concurrent findings of fact have been rightly rendered in our view, counsel Shri Dixit having taken us through the relevant papers.

facts.text: Plaintiffs offered to withdraw suit if original undertaking complied with and half costs paid.

anchor.surface_text: It must be mentioned in fairness to the ,plaintiffs that they offered to withdraw the suit for the return of the money if the original undertaking was substantially complied with and half the costs of the suit-which was not much-upto then incurred were also paid by Government.

facts.text: Government constituted committee, drew new plan, built 22-bed hospital after suit instituted.

anchor.surface_text: For, Government at long last constituted a new committee for the construction of the hospital building, drew up a new plan and built a 22-bed hospital in the same place. All this was after the legal action was instituted

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and we dismiss it with costs, an added injury to the public exchequer which we regret we cannot help.

facts.text: Sri Govind Narain declined to be a witness for Government.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Govind Narain having wisely declined to be a witness to the Governments version and the documents having testified to the truth of the plaintiffs case.

facts.text: No matching contribution of Rs. 30,000 by Government was made.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming substantial compliance as sufficient in law, the defendant has no case that any of the conditions has been carried out, not even the equal contribution,from Ox State exchequer

facts.text: Suit filed with notice under s. 80 CPC but no effect.

anchor.surface_text: Even a formal suit notice under s. 80 of the Civil Procedure Code for return of the sum given to the Collector on account of the failure of the charity did not shake the Government out of its neglectful tranquility.

holdings.text: There was no agreement to withdraw the claim, no estoppel arises, and the action is tenable.

anchor.surface_text: the essential issue turns on the nature and efficacy of the gift itself but before we discuss it the deck may as well be cleared by disposing of the, plea of agreement to withdraw the claim, estoppel on account of the defendant having acted thereon, and the companysequent untenability of the action. Both the companyrts have overruled it and we are in agreement with them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts overruled the plea; no final acceptance of offers, mere correspondence without agreement; plea abandoned in High Court.

holdings.text: The contribution of Rs. 30,000/- was for a charitable purpose as a hospital for women qualifies as medical relief for a section of the public.

anchor.surface_text: Was the companytribution of Rs. 30,000/- for a charitable purpose ? Lord Sterndale, M. R., said in the Court. of Appeal in In re Tutley 1  I am unable to find

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both parties agree; accords with law on charitable objects including medical relief for women.

holdings.text: The Indian Trusts Act, 1882 does not apply proprio vigore to public charitable trusts as it excludes them expressly.

anchor.surface_text: The Courts below have argued themselves into an application of s. 83 of the Trusts Act. Sri Dixit rightly objects to this companyrse because that Art relates only to private trusts, public charitable trusts, having been expressly, excluded from its ambit

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language excludes public trusts; lower courts erred in direct application.

holdings.text: Equity and good conscience principles from Trusts Act apply by analogy to public trusts.

anchor.surface_text: universal rules of equity and good companyscience upheld by the English Judges, though also sanctified by the statute relating to private trusts. The Court below have drawn inspiration from s. 83 of the Trusts Act and we are number inclined to find fault with them on that score

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common principles govern all trusts; s.83 reflects general equity applicable here.

holdings.text: The charitable object was specific, not general, precluding cy pres doctrine.

anchor.surface_text: Accepting that Dubey intended a charitable gift the first question that falls for- decision, as preliminary to the application of the cypres doctrine, in as to the nature of the charitable object-whether general or specific. if the former, the doctrine is attracted but if the latter it is repelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual findings show particularized intent: six-bed hospital, specific site, donor agency, matching grant; no general charitable intent.

holdings.text: Cy pres doctrine applies to inter vivos gifts for charity but only where general intent exists and trust effective; not here as conditions precedent failed ab initio.

anchor.surface_text: gifts inter vivos have been enforced cypres by companyrts although the general run of trusts where failure has been saved ,relates to testamentary dispositions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents support application to lifetime gifts but limited by general intent and effective dedication; distinguished here.

holdings.text: The donation was a conditional gift subject to conditions precedent (matching grant, donor construction agency, etc.) which were not fulfilled, so the gift did not take effect.

anchor.surface_text: that Shri Dubey made a companyditional gift and the, companyditions number having been fulfilled it just did number take effect. We see companysiderable force in this companytention

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual findings confirm conditions; no matching contribution even assuming substantial compliance suffices; analogies to property law (TP Act ss.25-26).

holdings.text: Upon failure of conditional charitable gift due to unfulfilled conditions precedent, a resulting trust arises in favor of the donor (or heirs).

anchor.surface_text: the legal consequence is a resulting trust in favour of the donor. The State companyld number keep the money and the suit was liable to be decreed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Equity prevents unjust enrichment; gift never vested; lower courts' decree affirmed.

holdings.text: Plaintiffs, as heirs, have right to demand repayment as gift failed and resulting trust arises.

anchor.surface_text: but the legal question still remains whether the plaintiffs stepping into the shoes of the donor have the right to demand repayment of the amount already made over.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stepping into donor's shoes; conditions failed leading to resulting trust.

holdings.text: Suit not liable to dismissal for non-joinder of other donors or charity.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Dixit has prayed for the dismissal of the suit for number- joinder of other donors and the charity. We mention it out of deference to companynsel but negative it as undeserving of companysideration.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; State liable to return Rs.30,000 with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and we dismiss it with companyts, an added injury to the public exchequer which we regret we cannot help.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All legal contentions rejected; facts support decree.

anchor.surface_text: Parker, J., as be then was, in In re Wilson  2  stressed the presence of a paramount general intention as distinguished from a particular limited purpose.

precedents.cited_proposition: paramount general charitable intention required for cy pres
precedents.cited_holding: Where, on the true construction of the will, no such paramount general charitable intention can be inferred, and where the gift, being in form a particular gift,-a gift for a particular purpose-and it being impossible to carry out that particular purpose, the whole gift is held to fail

precedents.citation: In re, Ulverston and District New Hospital Building Trust 3 1956 1 Ch. 022.

anchor.surface_text: In re, Ulverston and District New Hospital Building Trust 3  the Court held that in the case of a certain fund collected with the sole object of building and maintaining a new hospital and not for the general charitable purpose of improving facilities for medical

precedents.case_name: In re Ulverston and District New Hospital Building Trust
precedents.cited_proposition: no general charitable intent for specific hospital building fund; resulting trust if fails ab initio
precedents.cited_holding: no general charitable intent could be imputed to the donors and that the particular charitable purpose for which the fund was intended having failed ab initio, the money in the hands of the trustees received from identifiable sources was held on resulting trusts

precedents.citation: Commissioner, Lucknow Division v. Deputy Commissioner of Partapgar 1 A.I.R. 1937 P.C. 240.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner, Lucknow Division v. Deputy Commissioner of Partapgar 1  had to deal with the subscriptions paid to a committee for the purpose of fulfilling a specific and well-defined charitable purpose which could not be carried out on account of impracticability.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner Lucknow Division v. Deputy Commissioner of Partapgarh
precedents.cited_proposition: subscriptions for specific charitable purpose; if impracticable, return to subscribers
precedents.cited_holding: The money having been paid over to the committee, a complete trust was created to apply the funds in carrying out the object mentioned. If the object has become impracticable, the subscribers have a clear right to the return of their subscriptions pro rata.

anchor.surface_text: Lord Herschell, L.C., in the case of In re Rymer  2   laid down the law early in the day and it holds good even to-day.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between gift to charity generally and to particular institution
precedents.cited_holding: There is a distinction well settled by the authorities. There is one class of cases in which there is a gift to charity generally... There is another class, in which the testator shows an intention, not of general charity, but to give to some particular institution.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between general charity and particular institution

anchor.surface_text: In such cases courts have to consider the gift as a conditional one vide the ruling in Harish Chandra v. Hindu Sharnm Sewak Mandal 1 . In that case as the gift had failed the land reverted to the successor-in-title to the donor.

precedents.case_name: Harish Chandra v. Hindu Sharnam Sewak Mandal
precedents.cited_proposition: gift for specific charitable purpose rendered impossible treated as conditional; reverts to donor

precedents.citation: In re University of London Medical Sciences Institute Fund 2 1909 2 Ch. 18-9.

anchor.surface_text: Farewell, L.J., observed in this context in In re University of London Medical Sciences Institute Fund 2 . I do not think that anybody who was not a lawyer could for one moment doubt that the University were

precedents.case_name: In re University of London Medical Sciences Institute Fund
precedents.cited_proposition: money paid to trustees for specific purpose; if purpose fails, return to donor/subscribers
precedents.cited_holding: When money has once been paid over to the trustees in the lifetime of the donor a complete trust is created, and the money must be held on the trusts declared by the donor the right of the donor to a return of the money arises when the trust is on the face of it contingent on the proposed institute being called into being.

precedents.citation: In re Whites Trust 1 1886 Ch. Div. 449.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection reference may also be made to In re Whites Trust 1  where we may glean the same law laid down.

precedents.cited_proposition: law on conditional gifts to charity

anchor.surface_text: This has been expressed by Melbourne C. in Chamberlayne v. Brockett 2   in the following words If the gift in trust for the charity is itself conditional upon a future and uncertain event,

precedents.cited_proposition: conditional gift to charity subject to condition precedent; fails if not fulfilled
precedents.cited_holding: If the gift in trust for the charity is itself conditional upon a future and uncertain event, it is subject... to the same rules and principles any other estate depending for its coming into existence, upon a condition precedent. If the condition is never fulfilled, the estate never arises.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed with costs upholding the decree of the courts below for refund of Rs. 30,000/- to the plaintiffs on the basis of resulting trust due to failure of conditions of the donation.
